abstracts.cdata!:
This report evaluates the SCARP
            Transition Pilot Project for Pakistan. The outcome of the
            project was satisfactory. It fully achieved its ambitious
            institutional objectives. Responsibility for
            groundwater-based irrigation and vertical drainage was
            successfully transferred to the private sector without the
            angry demonstrations that had been anticipated. Despite
            having to absorb irrigation and drainage costs, farmers were
            able to increase their productivity enough to come out
            ahead. The sustainability of the project is likely. The main
            lesson from this pilot project is that Pakistan and the Bank
            lost an early opportunity to save significant operations and
            maintenance expenditures because they hung onto the public
            sector SCARP model for too long. From inception of the idea
            for a transition project in 1980, it took more than a decade
            to prove it would work. In preparing the follow-on projects,
            both the Bank and Borrower are mindful of the lessons of the
            SCARP Transition Pilot Project. The new project will focus
            its promotional efforts exclusively on community-owned wells
            rather than a large number of underutilized individually
            owned wells because community-owned wells will provide the
            greatest social benefits.

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Salinity Control and Reclamation
            (SCARP) Transition Pilot Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Salinity Control and
            Reclamation (SCARP) Transition Pilot Project for Pakistan
            was satisfactory. The project achieved most of its
            objectives, its impact on institutional development was
            partially successful, sustainability is likely, and both the
            Bank and Borrower performed satisfactorily. Several lessons
            can be learned from this project. First, in future projects,
            diesel-operated tubewells should be favored over electrical
            tubewells because their installation avoids costly
            distribution systems and connections. Second, large
            government subsidies are not needed to encourage farmers to
            install their own diesel-powered tubewells. Third, project
            supervisory consultants should be appointed at an early
            stage, preferably before negotiations, in order to avoid
            inordinate implementation delays. Fourth, increased IDA
            assistance may be needed for procurement of equipment
            through ICB procedures. Fifth, the responsibility for
            reviewing designs of on-farm water management (OFWM) works
            should be given to the project supervisory consultants in
            order to ensure design consistency. Finally, more attention
            should be given to monitoring and evaluation, particularly
            in this type of pilot project.

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Salinity Control and Reclamation
            (SCARP) Transition Pilot Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The SCARP Transition and Improvement
            Project will be the pilot phase of a  salinity control and
            reclamation project (SCARP) transition program to privatize
            ground water development in SCARP areas having adequate
            quality fresh groundwater. If proven feasible in the pilot
            phase, the program will be expanded to cover up to four
            million acres, and involve 7,500 public tubewells. The
            project objectives are to develop a replicable package of
            technical and institutional components for: (i) implementing
            Government policy of transferring the resposibility for
            groundwater pumpage in order to meet effectively both
            irrigation and drainage requirements; (ii) confirming that
            farmers, particularly smallholders, will be willing and able
            to participate in the privatization of groundwater
            development; and (iii) increasing agricultural production
            and farm incomes through improved use of surface and
            groundwater supplies, which are used conjunctively by farmers.
